title: VC Daily: SPAC Deal to Boost Biotech's Effort to Curb Lung Disease
text:
Two existing medicines, Roche's Esbriet and Ofev, from Boehringer Ingelheim, can slow lung scarring. Blade hopes to stop the disease from advancing and potentially reverse it. Its oral medicine is designed to target an enzyme that plays a vital role in the disease, according to Chief Executive Wendye Robbins.

After initial clinical studies in healthy volunteers, Blade is now preparing to test the drug in trials of people with the lung disease next year, Dr. Robbins said.

Blade's agreement to merge with Biotech Acquisition Co., a SPAC affiliated with Sprim Global Investments, will give Blade $254.3 million to finance its development of this and other drugs, including a $24.3 million financing that is being done alongside the merger deal. Investors in that financing include MPM and other returning backers, including Deerfield Management, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Pfizer Inc. and Osage University Partners.

And now on to the news...

Top News

Mega raise. Data-intelligence company Collibra NV has raised $250 million in funding, valuing the company at $5.25 billion, more than quadrupling its 2019 valuation, as venture capitalists bet on data-management companies to leverage data for business advantages, WSJ Pro's Isaac Taylor reports.

"We've seen this massive shift to cloud architecture," Felix Van de Maele, the company's chief executive and co-founder, said. "We really believe there is a fundamental category being created which we call data intelligence. We want to make sure we are really well-positioned to lead the category."

Sequoia Capital Global Equities and Brussels-based investment company Sofina led the round, along with participation from new investor Tiger Global Management LLC. Other investors include Battery Ventures, Dawn Capital LLP and CapitalG, a private-equity firm under Alphabet Inc.

Collibra's financing is another example of megarounds, deals valued at $100 million and up, gaining traction.

$12 Billion

The rough purchase price, excluding debt, that a private-equity-led group will pay for security-software company McAfee Corp. (WSJ)

Indonesia-Focused Alpha JWC Closes $433 Million Fund

Alpha JWC Ventures, an Indonesia-based early-stage venture-capital firm with three unicorns to its name, has secured $433 million for its third fund focused on Southeast Asia's booming technology sector, Ben Otto reports for WSJ Pro. The six-year-old firm run by former executives of Groupon Indonesia and venture-capital firm East Ventures said that its latest fund includes backing from Morgan Stanley Alternative Investment Partners, the World Bank's International Finance Corporation and Horizons Ventures Ltd., the venture-capital firm of Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing. The fund, coming after a 2016 raise of $50 million and a 2018 fund that garnered more than $120 million, more than triples the firm's assets under management to about $630 million. The fund surpassed an initial target of $250 million to $300 million, with three-quarters of previous investors returning and the number of U.S. investors doubling from the second fundraising, Alpha JWC said.

Nextdoor Surges in Trading Debut

Shares in Nextdoor Holdings Inc. surged Monday in their first day of trading as the social-networking app aimed at connecting local neighborhoods began life as a public company, WSJ reports. The San Francisco-based company that was founded a decade ago made its name helping people scout locally for dog walkers or gripe about neighbors. Nextdoor has gone public through a combination with Khosla Ventures Acquisition Co. II, a special-purpose acquisition company sponsored by venture-capital firm Khosla Ventures. Khosla Ventures valued Nextdoor at $4.3 billion in the blank-check merger, generating about $674 million in gross proceeds, including $270 million in private investments.

Vacation Rental Firms Vacasa, Sonder to Test Market With Public Offerings

A group of short-term rental companies are poised to go public, testing investor appetite for companies marketing themselves as alternatives to hotels, individual host listings and even traditional office space, WSJ reports. Professional managers of vacation homes and apartments have benefited from surging demand over the past year, as more Americans take advantage of remote work to book stays in small towns and resort destinations.

Sustainable Business Forum

WSJ Pro is hosting the Sustainable Business Forum on Nov. 17. The program includes an innovation showcase with AB InBev, Keurig Dr Pepper and City Developments Ltd. and a presentation by Jonah Goldman, managing director at Breakthrough Energy. Register here.

Industry News

Funds

Cadenza Ventures raised a $50 million fund to invest in digital-finance and blockchain technology. The fund's initial investments include Rain, Vauld, Lemon Cash, Tulip Protocol and Zebedee.

People

General Catalyst named Deep Nishar to the post of managing director. He was previously at SoftBank and LinkedIn.

OfferUp Inc., a mobile marketplace for local buyers and sellers, appointed Melinda Starbird as chief people and diversity officer. She previously led Auth0's people team. Bellevue, Wash.-based OfferUp is backed by investors including Andreessen Horowitz, Warburg Pincus, OLX Group and GGV Capital.

Exits

Eye-care provider Alcon agreed to acquire Ivantis, developer of a minimally-invasive glaucoma surgery device, for $475 million. Irvine, Calif.-based Ivantis is backed by investors including New Enterprise Associates, Delphi Ventures, Foresite Capital, RA Capital Management and Ascension Ventures.

AI vision company Ambarella Inc. completed its purchase of Oculii Corp., a provider of advanced AI software for radar perception, for $307.5 million. In May, Oculii said it raised $55 million in Series B funding co-led by Catapult Ventures and Conductive Ventures.

New Money

Contrast Security, a Los Altos, Calif.-based provider of code-security tools, scored a $150 million Series E round at a valuation of more than $1 billion. Liberty Strategic Capital led the funding, which saw participation from Warburg Pincus, Battery Ventures, General Catalyst, M12, AXA Venture Partners and Acero Capital.

HawkEye 360 Inc., a Herndon, Va. developer of a space-based radio frequency mapping and analytics system, completed a $145 million Series D round led by Insight Partners and Seraphim Space Investment Trust. Investors including Strategic Development Fund, Gula Tech Adventures, 116 Street Ventures, New North Ventures, Razor's Edge Ventures, NightDragon, SVB Capital, Shield Capital and others also participated in the new funding. Nick Sinai, managing director at Insight Partners, will join the company's board.

Drata Inc., a San Diego-based security and compliance automation platform, raised $100 million in Series B funding, giving the company a valuation of $1 billion. Iconiq Growth led the round, which included contributions from Alkeon Capital, Salesforce Ventures, GGV Capital, Cowboy Ventures and Leaders Fund.

H2O.ai, Mountain View, Calif.-based developer of software that helps businesses incorporate machine learning into their applications to make them more predictive, closed a $100 million Series E round. Commonwealth Bank of Australia led the funding, with Chief Data and Analytics Officer Andrew McMullan joining the company's board. Additional investors in the round included Pivot Investment Partners, Goldman Sachs Asset Management and Crane Venture Partners.

Bolt Logistics, a Canadian logistics and last-mile delivery provider, secured a 115 million Canadian dollar ($92.4 million) Series B round. Yaletown Partners led the round, which saw participation from Ingka Investments, Northleaf Capital Partners, Bank of Montreal, Kensington Capital, Whitecap Venture Partners, Intact Ventures and others.

Marengo Therapeutics Inc., a Cambridge, Mass.-based startup whose technology boosts anti-tumor T cells and promotes long-term protection against cancer, launched with an $80 million investment from ATP.

Curated, a San Francisco-based e-commerce platform that enables consumers to discover products online with the help of an expert, landed $75 million in Series C funding. CapitalG led the investment, which included additional support from Forerunner Ventures and Greylock.

BrightChamps, an India-based learning platform that teaches kids important life skills, picked up a $63 million investment from Premji Invest, GSV Ventures, 021 Capital and Beenext.

Landing AI, a Palo Alto, Calif.-based provider of tools for building and deploying AI systems in manufacturing, grabbed $57 million in Series A financing. McRock Capital led the investment, which included support from Insight Partners, Taiwania Capital, CPP Investments, Intel Capital, Samsung Catalyst Fund, Far Eastern Group's Drive Catalyst and others.

Matter Labs, a blockchain startup, snagged $50 million in Series B funding led by Andreessen Horowitz.

Fyllo, a Chicago-based digital marketing and compliance platform for cannabis and other highly regulated industries, collected $40 million in Series C funding. Led by Eminence Capital, the round saw additional participation from Longview Capital Advisors and ArrowMark Partners. Kristopher Koka, portfolio manager at Eminence Capital, will join the company's board.

Dispelix, a Finland-based maker of diffractive waveguide displays, raised $33 million in Series B funding. Lead investor Atlantic Bridge was joined by Lifeline Ventures, VTT Ventures, 3M Ventures and others in the round.
